headlines: EPA TAKES CONTROL OF TOLEDO WATER
data.full_script:
[ANCHOR_A] Good evening, I'm Patricia Holt. Here's what we're following this hour. The Senate Appropriations Committee remains deadlocked over the one-point-two trillion dollar infrastructure package, with rural broadband funding emerging as the key sticking point. Republican members are demanding stricter oversight provisions before moving forward.

[ANCHOR_B] Thanks Patricia. Federal mediators have walked away from negotiations at Dunmore Port as the workers' strike enters its fourth week. The National Labor Relations Board says talks have completely stalled over pension benefits, leaving the critical shipping hub paralyzed.

[ANCHOR_A] Marcus, the Environmental Protection Agency is escalating on two fronts tonight. The agency has launched a criminal investigation into Gulfmark Petrochemical after whistleblower documents allegedly revealed the company concealed toxic emissions data for eight years.

[ANCHOR_B] And Patricia, the EPA has also announced federal oversight of Toledo's entire municipal water system. This comes as the agency escalates its investigation into the city's ongoing water contamination crisis, with a regional administrator now taking direct control of operations.

[ANCHOR_A] We'll continue following these developing stories. I'm Patricia Holt, with Marcus Webb. Thanks for watching This News Now.

data.script: The Senate Appropriations Committee failed again today to advance the trillion-dollar infrastructure package, with rural broadband funding remaining the key sticking point. Republican members walked out after Democrats rejected a proposal to redirect sixty billion dollars from urban transit projects. [CHYRON: INFRASTRUCTURE BILL STALLED] Committee Chair Sarah Mitchell called the impasse "deeply disappointing" as construction season approaches. [B-ROLL: Empty committee room with scattered papers] More on this developing story after the break.

data.script: The Environmental Protection Agency has escalated its investigation into Toledo's water contamination crisis, announcing federal oversight of the city's entire municipal system. [CHYRON: EPA TAKES CONTROL OF TOLEDO WATER] Regional Administrator Sarah Chen cited immediate public health concerns after lead levels in four additional neighborhoods tested above emergency thresholds. City Manager Robert Hayes accused federal officials of overreach, but Governor Patricia Mills endorsed the EPA intervention. [B-ROLL: EPA trucks arriving at Toledo water treatment facility] More developments expected tomorrow.

data.script: The Environmental Protection Agency has opened a criminal investigation into Gulfmark Petrochemical after whistleblower documents revealed the company allegedly concealed toxic emissions data for eighteen months. [CHYRON: EPA LAUNCHES CRIMINAL PROBE] The Port Calloway facility handles benzene and sulfur compounds just three miles from residential areas. Company CEO Patricia Valdez denied wrongdoing in a statement today, calling the allegations baseless. [B-ROLL: EPA investigators in hazmat suits entering industrial complex] Louisiana Attorney General Michael Torres says his office is coordinating with federal prosecutors. More developments ahead.
